docs.lead_paragraph: In the middle of the ninth year of one of the longest economic booms in United States history, the rate of inflation is precisely zero. In June, the Labor Department reported yesterday, the closely watched Consumer Price Index -- which measures changes in the price of everything that American households buy, from candy bars to health care -- failed to register even the tiniest change.

headline.main: Inflation Didn't Budge in June, U.S. Says

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index registered zero in June; says 'core' inflation rate--which excludes volatile food and energy prices--edged up a tenth of a percent; Government reports jobless claims increased 11,000, to 310,000 for week ended on July 10, highest number in a month, but still level indicating healthy job market; graph and chart on consumer prices (M)
docs.snippet: In the middle of the ninth year of one of the longest economic booms in United States history, the rate of inflation is precisely zero.    In June, the Labor Department reported yesterday, the closely watched Consumer Price Index -- which measures...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 New Israeli Leader Says He's Ready to Talk to Syria Prime Minister Ehud Barak told President Clinton that Israel would embark on a ''serious effort'' in coming weeks to reopen talks with Syria, which is still formally at war with Israel. But Mr. Barak laid down several conditions as the price of peace, an Israeli official said. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: Donna Marie McIlwaine was 22 when she died on Feb. 8, 1997. She is buried in the Chili Rural Cemetery in upstate Scottsville, N.Y. The managed-care reform legislation that has been the focus of a furious debate in the Senate was essentially an effort to make it easier to save the lives of patients like Ms. McIlwaine.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column accuses Republican Party of engaging in 'tremendous scandal' in handling of managed-care reform legislation pending in Congress; says party has been flooded with money from managed-care industry and has subsequently given lip service to idea of protecting patients while doing bidding of companies that are source of cash (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dr. John C. Baldwin (letter, July 8) says ''health care should be a right in this country.'' I do not want the Government in charge of my health care; I want to choose my coverage. If Dr. Baldwin means the Government should help pay for health care, I agree -- if there are incentives for people to take care of themselves.
docs.abstract: Harriet H Harris letter, commenting on Dr John C Baldwin's July 8 letter which argued that health care should be an entitlement for Americans, says Government should help to pay for health care if there are incentives for people to take care of themselves (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans today showed that they were calling the shots in the Senate's managed care debate, approving their own measure on hospitalization for women undergoing mastectomies and turning back three efforts by Democrats to strengthen the rights of patients. In votes almost completely along party lines, the Republicans defeated the Democrats' second attempt in two days to broaden the bill to apply to all 161 million Americans with private health insurance. The Senate also killed a measure to insure patients' access to specialists, and it blocked the Democrats' attempt to require health plans to cover the costs of clinical trials and drugs. The Democrats argued that clinical trials once paid for by health insurance are being curtailed because managed-care plans were no longer paying for the routine patient costs.

headline.main: Senate G.O.P. Again Prevails on Health Care Bill

docs.abstract: Republican-controlled Senate, in 55-45 vote, approves measure that prevents insurance companies from forcing women to have mastectomies, turning back three attempts by Democrats to strengthen rights of patients by broadening bill to apply to all 161 million Americans with private health insurance; also kills measure to insure patients' access to specialists, and blocks Democrats' attempt to require health plans to cover costs of clinical trials and drugs; introduces multipart measure to guarantee patients emergency room care, as well as access to specialists; action follows defeat of broader Democratic versions of same provision that would have covered far more people; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Republicans today showed that they were calling the shots in the Senate's managed care debate, approving their own measure on hospitalization for women undergoing mastectomies and turning back three efforts by Democrats to strengthen the rights of...

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Ways and Means Committee approved the largest tax cut in nearly two decades tonight, brushing aside a veto threat by President Clinton in pursuit of a cherished Republican goal. The bill, which would reduce taxes by $864 billion over the next 10 years, advanced on a party-line vote of 23 to 13. It now goes to the full House, where it is likely to come to a final vote by the end of the month.

headline.main: House Panel Votes $864 Billion Tax Cut

docs.abstract: House Ways and Means Committee approves largest tax cut in nearly two decades, brushing aside veto threat by Pres Clinton in pursuit of cherished Republican goal; bill, which would reduce taxes by $864 billion over next 10 years, advances on 23-13 party-line vote; offers veritable wish list of tax cuts long sought by Republicans; would trim personal income tax rates by 10 percent and give additional break to married couples; would reduce top rate individuals pay on capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent, phase out tax on inheritances, cut taxes on interest and dividend income and provide deductions for health and long-term insurance; goes to full House for vote; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The House Ways and Means Committee approved the largest tax cut in nearly two decades tonight, brushing aside a veto threat by President Clinton in pursuit of a cherished Republican goal.    The bill, which would reduce taxes by $864 billion over the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Under a little-known provision in the 1996 Federal welfare law, New York has become eligible to receive several hundred million dollars a year from Washington to expand Medicaid coverage for one of its fastest-growing and most troubling uninsured populations: low-income working parents. But while nine other states, including Connecticut, have quietly begun to take advantage of the rule -- under which the Federal Government shoulders at least half of the states' costs for expanding the program -- New York has not. And so a broad alliance of hospitals, unions and advocates for the poor is coalescing to pressure Gov. George E. Pataki to use state money to prompt the release of Federal matching funds.

headline.main: Pataki Is Target in Bid to Expand Medicaid for Working Poor

docs.abstract: Broad alliance of hospitals, unions and advocates for poor is coalescing to pressure Gov George E Pataki to seek several hundred million dollars a year from Washington to expand Medicaid coverage for low-income working parents, under little-known provision in 1996 Federal welfare law; nine other states have begun to take advantage of rule; lobbying campaign will focus on New York State's $25 billion share of national tobacco settlement; Pataki wants to use most of tobacco money to help reduce state debt (M)
docs.snippet: Under a little-known provision in the 1996 Federal welfare law, New York has become eligible to receive several hundred million dollars a year from Washington to expand Medicaid coverage for one of its fastest-growing and most troubling uninsured...

docs.lead_paragraph: Provantage Health Services Inc., which helps insurance companies manage prescription drug benefits and claims, closed 18 percent above its offering price on its first day of trading. The company sold 5.6 million shares, or a 31 percent stake, at $18 each on Tuesday, raising $100.8 million. The stock closed at $21.1875, giving it a market value of $384.6 million. About 4.8 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Provantage works with more than 3,500 plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: On television screens across the nation's capital this week, the images were almost inescapable. One man complains about more government red tape. A mother worries that soaring insurance premiums could deny her sick daughter treatment. An employer frets about how health-care lawsuits could cost him his small business. As Senate Republicans rolled to a string of victories over Democrats on managed-care legislation this week, a barrage of such advertisements, sponsored by the Business Roundtable, provided punishing air support for the Republican offensive.

headline.main: Ads Enter Skirmish Over Health Care

docs.abstract: Health insurance companies and employers are crusading in television and newspaper advertisements against cost of Democratic health care bill, which they say would increase premiums and increase ranks of uninsured; coalition of managed-care companies plans to spend more than $5 million in 1999 on multilayered advertising and grassroots campaign; separate coalition of employers and insurance companies are mounting two-week, $1 million television, radio and newspaper advertising campaign that criticizes Democratic bill for raising premiums and swelling ranks of uninsured; some ads in television air war described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: On television screens across the nation's capital this week, the images were almost inescapable. One man complains about more government red tape. A mother worries that soaring insurance premiums could deny her sick daughter treatment. An employer...

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time, the Federal Government is acknowledging that nuclear weapons production during the cold war may have caused illnesses in thousands of workers, and the Clinton Administration on Thursday will announce legislation that would compensate many of them for their medical care and lost wages. Energy Secretary Bill Richardson detailed the legislation today in an interview, in which he depicted the workers as victims of the cold war and the rush to produce nuclear weapons. He said the safety standards, which had evolved since the 1940's, had been established in good faith but have since been deemed too weak to have protected workers.

headline.main: Work on Weapons Affected Health, Government Admits

docs.abstract: Federal Govt acknowledges for first time that nuclear weapons production during Cold War may have caused illnesses in thousands of workers, and Clinton Adm will announce legislation to compensate many for medical care and lost wages; Energy Sec Bill Richardson says workers were victims of Cold War and rush to produce nuclear weapons; says safety standards, which evolved since 1940's, were established in good faith but have since been deemed too weak to have protected workers; says he is reversing policy of 'denial of compensation;' photo (M)
